sentences.sentence: Recent comments made by talk show host Whoopi Goldberg about the Holocaust were followed by outrage, an apology, a two-week suspension and now more outrage by those who say that she either got off lightly, or is being unfairly punished.
While social media can always be counted on to generate more heat than light, we think the attention is worthwhile.
"The Holocaust," she said, "isn't about race.
It's not.
It's about man's inhumanity to man, that's what it's about."
She also said, "This is white people doing it to white people, so you're all going to fight amongst yourselves.
"Goldberg was right on one count: the Holocaust certainly was about mankind's inhumanity.
Although that statement's right as far as it goes, it doesn't go far enough.

Our take on the matter is straightforward: as far as the Nazis were concerned, the Jews were a race.Wilhelm Marr, the man who coined the term "antisemitism" in 1879, certainly believed that was the case.

Houston Stewart Chamberlain, an influential antisemite of the late 19th and early 20th century, wrote that Jews were genetically evil and were a problem that needed to be dealt with.Countless other practitioners of the pseudo-science of eugenics promoted the view that dangerous Jewish traits, including an innate hostility toward Christian civilization, were passed down from one generation to the next.
A Jew might convert from the faith, but that changed nothing.

"Der Giftpilz" ("The Poisonous Mushroom"), a grotesque piece of Nazi propaganda, taught German school children that the Jewish religion proclaims that only Jews are human and warns that there are "millions of gentiles who do not yet know (that) the Jew... is the cause of misery and distress, illness and death.
"The Nazis considered the Jews to be a racial problem that needed to be solved.
Six million Jewish men, women and children were murdered as part of their "Final Solution to the Jewish Question.
"Nor was the Holocaust simply a matter of white people fighting amongst themselves.
Fighting implies some level of equality between combatants.
The Holocaust wasn't that.
It was the deliberate, state-sponsored murder of helpless civilians.At the very least, Goldberg's comments provide what is now popularly known as a "teachable moment."
Consequences have been attached to her actions.
She has apologized.

We see no reason not to take her at her word and judge her sincerity based on her future behaviour.The discussion that has been generated in the last few days is important, especially in light of recent surveys that have highlighted a disturbing lack of knowledge about the Holocaust.

As an object lesson of what can happen if racism is left unopposed, the topic is too important to be left in the classroom.Beyond that, Goldberg's comments also gives us an opportunity to consider racism itself.
What does the word mean?

Is it applicable only to situations where perpetrator and victim are differentiated only by the colour of their skin, or can it more broadly encompass behaviours motivated by ideologies that attempt to raise one group of people over another?Definitions need not be seen as eternal.

Within the Jewish community, there is a healthy and passionate debate over the proper definition of antisemitism.If the definition of the longest hatred can, in the present moment, be up for discussion, perhaps we can use this moment to talk about a definition of racism that can become more inclusive without losing its power.
After all, it is quite clear that antisemitism and racism are two sides of the same coin.National PostBernie M. Farber is chair of the Canadian Anti-Hate Network.
Len Rudner sits on its advisory committee.

Both are past leaders of the Canadian Jewish Congress.Alex Rose: The complicated legacy of Holocaust education(https://nationalpost.com/opinion/alex-rose-the-complicated-legacy-of-holocaust-education)Avi Benlolo: Social media is dumbing down kids about the Holocaust(https://nationalpost.com/opinion/avi-benlolo-social-media-is-dumbing-down-the-holocaust) !
